newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE cocoa ends with pared losses, consolidating.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE cocoa ends with pared losses, consolidating.

text.p: LIFFE cocoa futures ended Tuesday with pared losses on late short-covering after early falls on sterling's jump against German mark, traders said.
But conditions remained lethargic with volume totalling just 2,634 lots by the finish.
"It's in no man's land," said one. "The market is taking stock after last weeks's sell-off which damaged sentiment. It needs time to recover."
After displaying some strength in the past two days, the market was knocked lower this morning by sterling's strength against the mark.
Sterling powered above 2.97 German marks to its highest since May 1991 early on Tuesday, boosted by stronger-than-expected UK inflation statistics for June.
By late Tuesday afternoon, sterling/mark stood at 2.9756 versus 2.9385/95 in late European trading on Monday.
LIFFE's September cocoa fell to a low of 1,024 stg a tonne before closing five higher at 1,043 stg. Its high-point was 1,045.
A strong sterling discouraged cocoa demand by continential European buyers.
Sterling also rose against the dollar, reaching near seven-month highs after the unexpectedly strong rise in the UK inflation suggested there may be an increase in interest rates this week.
Despite the setback on cocoa, traders said the firmer fundamental picture remained intact.
In the longer-term, the industry is worried over the adverse impact of the El Nino weather pattern, which could set in by December, on the future harvest.
In the medium-term, there's a possibility of a late crop in West Africa although the supply prospects have improved significantly.
Private pod counters touring the Ivory Coast were now turning to the opinion that a big crop was likely next year, with some expecting a bigger crop than in 1996/97, broker GNI said.
News from Abidjan put Ivorian arrivals at 1.05-1.06 million tonnes for the 1996/97 (Oct-Sept) crop by July 4 compared to around 1.148 million at the same stage in the record 1995/96 season.

Elsewhere, the CFTC Commitments of Traders report released after Monday's close showed speculators (non-commercials and nonreportables) were net long 33,724 lots as of July 1, but did not reflect the recent sharp sell-off. -- Jalil Hamid, London newsroom +44 171 542 4985
